articles.headline: Fed Affirms Plan to End Mortgage Intervention
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve’s move to stop buying mortgage-backed securities shows a degree of confidence that it can eliminate that pillar of support without undermining the nation’s economic recovery.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve’s move to stop buying mortgage-backed securities shows a degree of confidence that it can eliminate that pillar of support without undermining the nation’s economic recovery.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve on Tuesday affirmed its plan to stop buying mortgage-backed securities, expressing a degree of confidence that it could eliminate that pillar of support without undermining the nation’s economic recovery.

articles.headline: Followers of Sadr Emerge Stronger After Iraq Elections
articles.snippet: Discipline has thrust the followers of Moktada al-Sadr, the radical Shiite cleric, to the brink of perhaps their greatest political influence.
articles.abstract: Discipline has thrust the followers of Moktada al-Sadr, the radical Shiite cleric, to the brink of perhaps their greatest political influence.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — The followers of Moktada al-Sadr, a radical cleric who led the Shiite insurgency against the American occupation, have emerged as Iraq’s equivalent of Lazarus in elections last week, defying ritual predictions of their demise and now threatening to realign the nation’s balance of power.

articles.headline: The Perils of Pay Less, Get More
articles.snippet: Demand for government services grows, but taxes don’t. This is the main reason for our budget problems.
articles.abstract: Demand for government services grows, but taxes don’t. This is the main reason for our budget problems.
articles.lead_paragraph: As a society gets richer, its tax rates tend to rise.

articles.headline: Ailing Euro Seen as a Signal of Deeper Woes on Continent
articles.snippet: A weaker euro is beneficial for European exporters, but it sends a troubling message about the bloc’s growth prospects.
articles.abstract: A weaker euro is beneficial for European exporters, but it sends a troubling message about the bloc’s growth prospects.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — It used to be easy to sum up the way European business executives viewed exchange rates: a strong dollar was good; a strong euro was bad.

articles.headline: Underwater Cable an Alternative to Electrical Towers
articles.snippet: In a string of projects that has so far provoked only token opposition from environmentalists, some companies are putting power lines under water.
articles.abstract: In a string of projects that has so far provoked only token opposition from environmentalists, some companies are putting power lines under water.
articles.lead_paragraph: Generating 20 percent of America’s electricity with wind, as recent studies proposed, would require building up to 22,000 miles of new high-voltage transmission lines. But the huge towers and unsightly tree-cutting that these projects require have provoked intense public opposition.

articles.headline: How Privacy Vanishes Online
articles.snippet: Using bits of data from social network sites, researchers gleaned names, ages and even Social Security numbers.
articles.abstract: Using bits of data from social network sites, researchers gleaned names, ages and even Social Security numbers.
articles.lead_paragraph: If a stranger came up to you on the street, would you give him your name, Social Security number and e-mail address?

articles.headline: States’ Rights Is Rallying Cry for Lawmakers
articles.snippet: Driven by conservatives’ anxiety about federal authority, state declarations of their rights are on a roll.
articles.abstract: Driven by conservatives’ anxiety about federal authority, state declarations of their rights are on a roll.
articles.lead_paragraph: Whether it’s correctly called a movement, a backlash or political theater, state declarations of their rights — or in some cases denunciations of federal authority, amounting to the same thing — are on a roll.

articles.headline: Taliban Hit Back in Marja With a Campaign of Intimidation
articles.snippet: Though fighters have left the Afghan town, agitators have remained as part of an effort to undermine U.S. attempts to establish a strong local government.
articles.abstract: Though fighters have left the Afghan town, agitators have remained as part of an effort to undermine U.S. attempts to establish a strong local government.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Taliban have begun waging a campaign of intimidation in Marja that some local Afghan leaders worry has jeopardized the success of an American-led offensive there meant as an early test of a revised military approach in Afghanistan.
